course.subject: LANG
course.name: Chinese for Non-Chinese Language Background Students III
course.description: This course builds on the groundwork laid in LANG 1120 and LANG 1121, and takes students to a higher level of understanding of spoken Chinese and a stronger communicative competence in using Chinese in daily, social and professional situations. The course is restricted to students with non-Chinese language backgrounds. Instructors’ approval is required for students with Chinese backgrounds who are from international schools of Hong Kong, China Mainland and other Asian countries, also for overseas students with either Mandarin or Cantonese language backgrounds. For students without prerequisite but with prior Chinese learning experience of approximately 100 hours may seek instructors’ approval to enroll in the course.
course.exclusions: HKDSE/HKALE/HKCEE/JEE Chinese, LANG 1113, LANG 1114 (prior to 2017-18), LANG 1115 (prior to 2017-18), LANG 1116 (prior to 2017-18), LANG 1117, LANG 1118

reviews.author: abcz
reviews.comment_content:
It will be divided into 4 basic topics:
Unit One: Making Friends
Unit Two: Studying Chinese
Unit Three: Sports and Health
Unit Four: Shopping and Clothing.

Relatively easy if you already learn basic mandarin.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very good and kind professor. She is very friendly and helpful. She will check up on her students, let us make an appointment to talk to her. She also gives feedback given back to our assignment so that we can improve for finals. In the class, she combines different types of teaching, so it is not boring. In class, she will form small groups so we can have discussion.
reviews.comment_grading: Absolute and good grading. The cut-offs are: 85<A range < 100. 85 - 90 = A - , 90 - 95 = A, 95-100 = A+.
reviews.comment_workload: Relatively light workload. As I remember,  during the midterm period, there will be speaking, writing assessment and written test in class. And at the end of the semester, there will also be speaking, writing assessment and written test.

reviews.author: klaw
reviews.comment_content: Pretty basic such as sports, weather, major, food, conjuctions, etc. Should be pretty easy if you have a foundation in Chinese language. The materials are equal to HSK 2.
reviews.comment_teaching: Basic teaching. Very friendly and kind, like to make jokes and share about her life experiences. Combines actual teaching with group exercises and discussions, so classes were less boring.
reviews.comment_grading: Very generous grading. LANG courses are absolute and the cutoff points that I remember her say are: >85 A-, >90 A, >95 A+. But if she thinks you are really trying and are only 2-3 points away from the cutoff point, she will boost you 1 subgrade. I got 92% but she gave me A+ for the final grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload are not as heavy as she only requires us to submit 4 assignments throughout the semester, in which 2 are the scripts for our Oral (that we have to do anyway) and the last one is for the second Written assessment. And it is graded based on submission so you don't have to worry. Also, if you are having a busy week you can ask her to postpone the due date and she will be very understanding.

reviews.author: potat0
reviews.comment_content:
Introducing yourself, your study life, leisure and sports, food, shopping....
It reviews some content covered in levels 1 and 2 with a much larger emphasis on writing ( you will need to write, not type a fair a mount of Chinese characters)
You should be familiar with HSK 1 and 2 characters and vocab and if you had a hard time in level 2 I wouldn't suggest taking the course without self studying first.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very good prof. A bit sensitive when it comes to HK/Mainland relations but she really adjusts the pace of the class so everyone feels comfortable but challenged enough at the same time. If you need extra help she will provide you with resources and will be nice to you as long as you work.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading:
100-95: A+
95-90: A
90-85: A-
I forgot the rest...
- Attendance: not graded but gives a boost if your grade is close to the cutoff
- 4 x Homework (graded on submission, not how correct they are)
- Midterm and final (in class): writing, reading, grammar and presentation (they have the same weight )
reviews.comment_workload: Really depends on your true background in Chinese. If like me level 1 was your very first contact with mandarin, then the workload is quite high,  especially if you are not familiar with characters. Huge jump from level 2 in terms of fluency required and speed of understanding, so you will need to spend sever hours regularly on the course if you truly want to get something from it.
